title: GE CARESCAPE Canvas Monitor – Power Issue – Will Not Turn On
description: Structured Clinical Engineering troubleshooting for a GE CARESCAPE Canvas monitor that will not power on.

steps.title: Ensure Patient Safety First
instructions: If the monitor is in clinical use:
Transfer the patient to a functioning monitor first.
Do not troubleshoot while the monitor is actively required for patient care.
Confirm the device is safe to remove from service before proceeding.

steps.title: Verify AC Power at the Outlet
instructions: Confirm the monitor is connected to a known-working hospital-grade outlet.
Test the outlet with a known-good device (lamp, outlet tester, etc.).
If plugged into a power strip, isolation transformer, or UPS, verify that device is powered on and functioning.
If available, try a different known-working wall outlet.
Why this matters: Loss of upstream power is the most common and simplest cause of a “dead” monitor.

steps.title: Inspect and Reseat the Power Cord
instructions: Visually inspect the power cord for:
Cuts or fraying
Bent or damaged prongs
Loose connector ends
Reseat the cord firmly at:
The wall outlet
The rear AC inlet of the monitor
If available, swap with a known-good hospital-grade power cord and attempt to power on again.
Why this matters: A loose or internally failed cord can mimic total device failure.

steps.title: Confirm the Rear Power Switch Position
instructions: Verify the rear power rocker switch is in the ON position.
Then press the front power button.
Do not assume the switch position without physically checking it.

steps.title: Observe for Any Signs of Activity
instructions: When attempting to power on, closely observe:
Front LED indicators
Brief screen flash
Audible fan noise
Clicking sounds
Even minimal activity suggests partial power presence and helps narrow down whether the failure is complete or localized.

Cause: “Unit does not power on with known-working outlet and known-good power cord. Rear switch verified ON. No indicator lights, fan noise, or display activity observed. Suspected internal power supply failure.”
Resolution: “Removed from service and tagged Out of Service.”
“Sent to Biomed shop for bench evaluation.”

helpfulDetails: Final device status (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: GE Healthcare MAC VU360 – Leads Not Detected / Noisy ECG
description: Troubleshooting guide for lead-off messages and noisy ECG waveforms on a GE Healthcare MAC VU360 electrocardiograph.

steps.title: Check Electrode Placement and Skin Prep
instructions: Ensure electrodes are placed correctly.
Confirm skin is clean and dry.
Replace dried, expired, or loose electrodes.

steps.title: Inspect Lead Wires and Connections
instructions: Verify lead wires are firmly attached.
Inspect patient cable for damage.
Ensure trunk cable is securely connected.

steps.title: Reduce Electrical Interference
instructions: Move ECG cables away from power cords.
Ensure patient is not touching metal surfaces.
Minimize cable tangling.

steps.title: Confirm Proper Lead Selection
instructions: Verify correct lead configuration.
Ensure selected mode matches cable type.

steps.title: Test with Known-Good Cable
instructions: Swap with known-good patient cable.
Reassess waveform quality.

steps.title: Perform Simulator Test
instructions: Connect ECG simulator.
Run rhythm simulation.
Evaluate waveform stability.

CCR.Complaint: Leads not detected and ECG waveform noisy.
CCR.Cause: Loose electrodes or intermittent cable connection causing artifact and lead-off detection.
CCR.Resolution: Replaced electrodes and secured connections. Verified proper operation with ECG simulator.

title: GE Healthcare MAC VU360 – Printer Not Printing / Poor Print Quality
description: Troubleshooting steps for addressing printer not printing or producing poor print quality on a GE Healthcare MAC VU360.

steps.title: Confirm the Printer Is Enabled
instructions: Access the MAC VU360 menu and verify that the internal printer is enabled.
If disabled, turn the printer on through the settings menu.
Try a controlled print command to test.

steps.title: Check Paper Supply
instructions: Open the printer compartment and confirm correct paper is loaded.
Ensure paper is clean, flat, and correctly oriented.
Replace any paper that looks old, curled, or dirty.

steps.title: Inspect Printer Roll and Sensors
instructions: Check the paper roll for tears or dust buildup.
Clean the paper path and sensors with a soft dry cloth or air duster.
Verify that sensors firmly detect paper presence.

steps.title: Check Print Quality Settings
instructions: Navigate to print quality settings in the system menu.
Ensure contrast/density settings are at appropriate levels.
Try increasing density slightly if output is faint.

steps.title: Perform a Printer Self-Test
instructions: Access the printer test option from the system menu.
Observe if the self-test prints correctly.
If self-test fails or comes out poorly, suspect printer hardware or thermal head issue.

steps.title: Check for Error Messages
instructions: Watch the monitor for any printer error codes.
Record the exact message for documentation.
Consult service manual for the specific code meaning.

CCR.Complaint: Printer will not print or prints very light and poor quality.
CCR.Cause: Printer self-test fails with faint or blank output despite correct paper and settings. Suspected thermal head or internal printer failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed from service and sent for repair or printer mechanism replaced on bench.

helpfulDetails: Final status (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: ICU Medical CADD-Solis – Keypad Not Responding
description: Troubleshooting guide for keypad failures on the ICU Medical CADD-Solis infusion pump.

steps.title: Confirm the Pump Is Not Frozen
instructions: Observe whether the display is updating.
Check for active alarms or error messages.
Attempt multiple buttons.

steps.title: Power Cycle the Pump
instructions: Turn the pump off.
Wait at least 10 seconds.
Turn it back on and allow it to fully boot.

steps.title: Inspect the Keypad Surface
instructions: Check membrane for cracks or bubbling.
Look for worn or faded button areas.
Inspect for signs of fluid intrusion or residue.

steps.title: Test All Buttons Individually
instructions: Press each button one at a time.
Determine if failure is isolated or entire keypad is unresponsive.

CCR.Complaint: Keypad buttons not responding; unable to program infusion.
CCR.Cause: Specific keypad buttons remain non-functional after power cycle. Suspected keypad membrane failure or internal ribbon cable issue.
CCR.Resolution: Removed pump from service and sent for repair.

title: ICU Medical CADD-Solis – Air-in-Line Alarms
description: Troubleshooting air-in-line alarms for an ICU Medical CADD-Solis infusion pump.

steps.title: Inspect the Tubing and Cassette for Air
instructions: Stop the pump if running.
Visually inspect tubing from cassette to patient for air bubbles.
Check the cassette reservoir for air.
If air is present, prime the tubing according to manufacturer instructions and remove all visible air before restarting infusion.
Even small air bubbles near the sensor can trigger alarms.

steps.title: Check Tubing Connections
instructions: Ensure all luer connections are secure and tight.
Inspect for loose or partially connected segments.
Confirm no leakage points where air could enter.
Loose connections can introduce air during infusion.

steps.title: Confirm Proper Cassette Installation
instructions: Remove and reseat the cassette firmly.
Ensure tubing is correctly aligned in the cassette pressure channel.
Verify the cassette is fully seated and locked.
Misalignment or partially seated cassettes can allow air to be detected incorrectly.

steps.title: Inspect Pump Orientation and Placement
instructions: Pump should be positioned per manufacturer guidelines (usually upright).
Avoid placing the pump upside down or on uneven surfaces.
Ensure tubing runs freely to the patient without tension.
Incorrect orientation can cause the sensor to detect air incorrectly.

steps.title: Power Cycle the Pump
instructions: Turn the pump off.
Wait at least 10 seconds.
Turn it back on.
Reinstall cassette and tubing.
Temporary sensor glitches may clear after a reboot.

steps.title: Test with Known-Good Tubing and Cassette
instructions: Replace cassette and tubing with new or verified working components.
Attempt infusion at same settings.
If alarms stop: original cassette or tubing was likely defective or had trapped air.
If alarms continue: internal air-in-line sensor or logic issue is likely.

steps.title: Observe Alarm Behavior
instructions: Document whether the alarm occurs immediately upon starting infusion.
Check if there is visible air near the sensor when alarm triggers.
See if adjusting tubing or re-priming stops the alarm.
Observe whether the alarm occurs only at certain infusion rates or settings.

CCR.Complaint: Pump repeatedly alarms for air-in-line; tubing and cassette appear clear.
CCR.Cause: Tubing and cassette inspected and replaced, pump power-cycled. False air-in-line alarms persist. Suspected internal sensor or pressure plate failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed pump from service, labeled out of service, sent for repair.

helpfulDetails: Alarm occurs immediately or during infusion
Final disposition (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: ICU Medical CADD-Solis – Occlusion Alarms
description: Basic troubleshooting for occlusion alarms on ICU Medical CADD-Solis infusion pumps, including false occlusions.

steps.title: Check Tubing Path for Obstructions
instructions: Stop the pump if running.
Inspect the entire infusion set from the cassette to the patient.
Ensure tubing is free of kinks or sharp bends, not pinched under clamps or clothing, and correctly seated in the cassette pressure channel.
Even minor kinks can trigger false occlusion alarms.

steps.title: Inspect the Cassette Pressure Plate and Tubing Channel
instructions: Remove the cassette.
Look for debris or dried medication in the tubing channel, warped or cracked pressure plate, improperly seated tubing.
Clean per facility policy. Misalignment or debris can cause the pump to detect pressure incorrectly.

steps.title: Confirm Correct Cassette and Tubing
instructions: Ensure tubing type matches therapy type (continuous, PCA, or intermittent).
Verify tubing is compatible with CADD-Solis cassettes.
Confirm tubing is not expired or damaged.
Incorrect or worn tubing can trigger intermittent occlusion alarms.

steps.title: Check Pump Orientation and Placement
instructions: Position pump per manufacturer guidelines (usually upright or at specified angle).
Ensure tubing runs freely to the patient without sharp bends or tension.
Avoid hanging the pump upside-down or placing tubing under tension.
Pressure sensors can falsely trigger if pump orientation is incorrect.

steps.title: Power Cycle the Pump
instructions: Turn the pump off.
Wait at least 10 seconds.
Turn it back on.
Reinstall cassette and tubing.
Temporary sensor glitches can clear after a reboot.

steps.title: Test with a Known-Good Cassette and Tubing
instructions: Replace cassette and tubing with new or verified working components.
Attempt infusion at same settings.
If false alarms stop: original cassette or tubing is likely defective.
If alarms continue: internal occlusion/pressure sensor issue or pump logic error is likely.

steps.title: Observe Alarm Patterns
instructions: Document if alarm occurs immediately upon starting infusion or at specific rates/pressures.
Check for fluid in tubing or cassette causing air bubbles.
See if alarm clears when tubing is gently adjusted or re-seated.
Pattern observation helps determine whether cause is external or internal.

CCR.Complaint: Pump repeatedly alarms for occlusion; tubing appears patent.
CCR.Cause: Tubing inspected and re-seated, cassette replaced, pump power-cycled. False occlusion persists. Suspected internal pressure sensor or pressure plate failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed pump from service, labeled out of service, sent for repair.

helpfulDetails: Alarm occurs immediately or during infusion
Final disposition (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: ICU Medical CADD-Solis – Cassette Error / Not Recognized
description: Troubleshooting guide for Cassette Error or Cassette Not Recognized alarms on a CADD-Solis Ambulatory Infusion Pump.

steps.title: Remove and Re-seat the Cassette
instructions: Stop the pump if running.
Remove the cassette completely.
Inspect the cassette connection area.
Reinstall the cassette firmly until it clicks/locks into place.
Ensure cassette is properly aligned, fully seated, and locked securely.

steps.title: Inspect the Cassette for Damage
instructions: Check cassette housing and tubing channel.
Inspect keying features and alignment tabs.
Look for cracked plastic, warped edges, or fluid contamination.
Replace cassette if damaged.

steps.title: Confirm Cassette Compatibility
instructions: Verify cassette type matches programmed therapy.
Confirm volume matches pump configuration.
Compare with known-good cassette if unsure.

steps.title: Inspect Pump Cassette Latch Area
instructions: Check for debris or dried medication residue.
Inspect latch mechanism.
Clean per facility policy if needed.

steps.title: Power Cycle the Pump
instructions: Turn pump off.
Wait 10 seconds.
Turn back on and reinstall cassette.

steps.title: Test with a Known-Good Cassette
instructions: Install new unused cassette.
Attempt to start infusion.
If error persists, suspect internal pump issue.

CCR.Complaint: Pump displaying 'Cassette Error' — cassette not recognized.
CCR.Cause: Cassette reseated and replaced with known-good cassette. Error persists. Suspected internal cassette detection sensor or latch failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed pump from service and sent for repair.

helpfulDetails: Final disposition (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: Kendall SCD 700 Series – Display / Control Panel Malfunction
description: Troubleshooting display and control panel issues for a Kendall SCD 700 Series sequential compression device.

steps.title: Confirm the Unit Has Power
instructions: Ensure the unit is plugged into a live outlet.
Verify the power switch is ON.
Listen for internal sounds (fan or pump initialization).

steps.title: Adjust Screen Visibility
instructions: Check for brightness settings if adjustable.
Look closely for faint text that may indicate a backlight issue.
Shine a flashlight at an angle to see if text is present but dim.

steps.title: Check for a Frozen Interface
instructions: Attempt to press multiple buttons.
Observe whether any LEDs respond.
Check whether sleeves are still inflating despite the frozen display.

steps.title: Power Cycle the Unit
instructions: Turn the unit OFF.
Wait at least 10 seconds.
Turn it back ON and allow full startup.

CCR.Complaint: Display blank or control buttons unresponsive.
CCR.Cause: Power verified, unit power cycled, no visible backlight or response from control panel. Suspected display/backlight or control board failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed device from service and sent for bench evaluation.

helpfulDetails: Screen blank or faint image visible

title: Kendall SCD 700 Series – Alarms Going Off Unnecessarily
description: Troubleshooting frequent or nuisance alarms on a Kendall SCD 700 Series sequential compression device.

steps.title: Identify the Exact Alarm Message
instructions: Read the alarm message carefully.
Document the exact wording.
Note whether it is constant or intermittent.

steps.title: Check Tubing Connections
instructions: Disconnect and fully reseat all tubing connectors.
Ensure connectors are fully inserted.
Gently tug to confirm they are secure.

steps.title: Inspect Tubing for Micro-Leaks or Kinks
instructions: Check for hairline cracks, pinholes, soft spots, or sharp bends.
Ensure tubing is not pinched under bed rails or wheels.

steps.title: Inspect Sleeves
instructions: Check for torn seams or worn Velcro.
Ensure sleeves are wrapped snugly and evenly.
Confirm correct sleeve size.

steps.title: Swap Sleeves and Tubing
instructions: Replace sleeves with known-good accessories if available.
Swap left and right sides to see if the alarm follows the accessory.

steps.title: Power Cycle the Unit
instructions: Turn the unit off.
Wait at least 10 seconds.
Restart therapy and observe.

CCR.Complaint: Repeated leak alarm despite tubing appearing connected.
CCR.Cause: Tubes reseated, sleeves swapped, alarm persisted on same port. Suspected internal pressure sensor or valve issue.
CCR.Resolution: Removed from service and sent for bench evaluation.

title: Kendall SCD 700 Series – Pressure Too Low or Inconsistent
description: Troubleshooting low, weak, or inconsistent compression pressure on a Kendall SCD 700 Series SCD.

steps.title: Confirm Therapy Mode and Settings
instructions: Verify correct therapy mode is selected (calf vs. thigh).
Confirm therapy has fully started and is cycling normally.
Ensure no standby or paused state is active.

steps.title: Check Sleeve Application
instructions: Ensure sleeves are wrapped snugly and evenly.
Confirm correct sleeve size.
Avoid loose wrapping.

steps.title: Inspect Tubing for Leaks or Kinks
instructions: Check tubing for cracks or pinholes.
Inspect for loose fittings.
Ensure tubing is not kinked or pinched.

steps.title: Check Connections at the Ports
instructions: Fully reseat tubing connectors.
Listen for air leaks.
Gently wiggle connectors during cycling to detect intermittent leaks.

steps.title: Swap Sleeves and Tubing
instructions: Swap left and right sleeves.
Replace tubing with known-good set if available.
Observe whether issue follows accessory or stays with port.

CCR.Complaint: Compression pressure weak and inconsistent.
CCR.Cause: Sleeves and tubing inspected and swapped; issue remained on same port. Suspected internal valve or pump degradation.
CCR.Resolution: Removed device from service and sent for bench evaluation.

helpfulDetails: Pump audible and consistent: yes / no

title: Kendall SCD 700 Series – One or More Sleeves Not Inflating
description: Troubleshooting guide for Kendall SCD 700 Series when one or more sleeves are not inflating properly.

steps.title: Confirm the Unit Is Powered and Running
instructions: Ensure the device is powered on.
Confirm there are no active alarms.
Verify the therapy mode is started (not just powered on).

steps.title: Check Sleeve and Tubing Connections
instructions: Confirm tubing is fully seated into the correct port.
Listen or feel for a click when inserting connectors.
Inspect for partially disconnected tubing.
Swap ports (left/right) to see if the issue follows the sleeve or stays with the port.

steps.title: Inspect the Tubing for Kinks or Damage
instructions: Check the entire length of tubing for sharp bends.
Ensure tubing is not pinched under bed rails or wheels.
Look for cracks, tears, or punctures.

steps.title: Inspect the Sleeves
instructions: Check for visible tears or separated seams.
Ensure Velcro allows proper snug wrap.
Confirm sleeves are wrapped snugly but not overly tight.

steps.title: Swap Sleeves to Isolate the Issue
instructions: Disconnect both sleeves.
Swap left and right sleeves.
Observe whether the issue follows the sleeve or remains with the port.

CCR.Complaint: One sleeve not inflating; right leg no compression.
CCR.Cause: Tubing and sleeve inspected, swapped ports, issue remained on right port. Suspected internal valve failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed device from service and sent for bench evaluation.

helpfulDetails: Issue followed sleeve or stayed with port

title: Kendall SCD 700 Series – Will Not Power On
description: Basic power troubleshooting for a Kendall SCD 700 Series sequential compression device.

steps.title: Confirm Power Source
instructions: Ensure the unit is plugged into a live AC outlet.
Test the outlet with another device to confirm power availability.
If using the battery option (if applicable), verify batteries are installed correctly and fully charged.

steps.title: Check the Power Switch
instructions: Ensure the power switch is fully in the 'ON' position.
Listen or look for any indicator lights.
Sometimes the switch may feel 'on' but have poor internal contact.

steps.title: Inspect the Power Cord and Connectors
instructions: Examine the cord for frays, cuts, or exposed wires.
Confirm all connectors are clean, free from debris, and fully seated.
Replace any damaged cord immediately — do not operate with exposed wires.

steps.title: Test With a Known-Good Outlet or Battery
instructions: Plug the unit into a different, verified outlet.
If battery-operated, swap with a fully charged battery pack if available.

steps.title: Observe Indicator Lights or Sounds
instructions: Note LED indicators or audible beeps.
No lights may indicate a blown fuse, internal PCB failure, or battery problem.
Observe any unusual behaviors (clicks, beeps, flickering) when attempting to power on.

steps.title: Check Safety Interlocks
instructions: Ensure compression sleeves and tubing are correctly connected.
Some units have interlocks that prevent power-on if accessories are not properly seated.

steps.title: Consider Internal Fuses or Circuitry
instructions: Certain SCD 700 units have an internal fuse accessible through a service panel.
Only inspect if you are trained or authorized; improper handling can be hazardous.
If unsure, skip and escalate to Clinical Engineering or the manufacturer.

CCR.Complaint: Kendall SCD 700 will not power on; no indicator lights.
CCR.Cause: Power source verified, switch functional, cord and connectors intact, unit remains unresponsive. Suspected internal electronics failure (fuse or PCB).
CCR.Resolution: Removed device from service, labeled Out of Service, sent for repair.

helpfulDetails: Any unusual sounds when powering on
Final disposition (returned to service, sent for repair)

title: Welch Allyn Connex 6000 Series – Touchscreen Calibration / Dead Spots
description: Basic troubleshooting for a Welch Allyn Connex 6000 Series monitor when the touchscreen is misaligned or has dead spots.

steps.title: Check for Obstructions or Contamination
instructions: Inspect the screen for dirt, moisture, or residue.
Clean the screen using an approved disinfectant wipe and allow it to dry fully.
Make sure there is no plastic film, tape, or label covering the screen.
Debris or moisture can interfere with touch detection and make the screen appear miscalibrated.

steps.title: Confirm the Monitor Is Not Frozen
instructions: Try pressing several different areas of the screen.
Observe whether any buttons respond at all.
Check if the display is updating or appears stuck.
A frozen screen can look like a calibration or dead-spot issue.

steps.title: Power Cycle the Monitor
instructions: Turn the monitor off.
Wait at least 10 seconds.
Power the monitor back on and allow it to fully boot.
Temporary software issues can sometimes affect touchscreen response.

steps.title: Check for Visible Screen Damage
instructions: Look closely for cracks, pressure marks, or discoloration.
Gently touch different areas of the screen and note where input is not detected.
Physical damage can cause permanent dead zones on the touchscreen.

steps.title: Observe the Behavior
instructions: Note whether touches register in the wrong location (misalignment).
Note whether certain areas do not respond at all.
Record any error messages or unusual behavior.
This helps determine whether the issue is calibration-related or a failed touch panel.

CCR.Complaint: Touchscreen not responding correctly; dead spots present.
CCR.Cause: Screen cleaned and inspected, power cycled, no visible damage. Touch input still misaligned / unresponsive in certain areas. Suspected touchscreen digitizer failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed monitor from service, labeled out of service, sent for repair. Tagged for bench evaluation by CE.

helpfulDetails: Final disposition (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: Philips V60 Ventilator – Fails Self-Test / Flow Sensor Error
description: Basic troubleshooting for a Philips V60 ventilator reporting a flow sensor error or failing self-test.

steps.title: Inspect the Patient Circuit
instructions: Make sure all tubing connections are secure and fully seated.
Check for cracks, holes, or loose fittings.
Confirm there are no kinks or obstructions that could block flow.
Even a small leak or disconnection can trigger a flow sensor error.

steps.title: Check the Flow Sensor Module
instructions: Locate the flow sensor in the circuit (usually near the patient connection or ventilator port).
Make sure it is properly installed and seated.
Inspect for visible damage, moisture, or condensation.
A loose or wet sensor can prevent the ventilator from reading flow accurately.

steps.title: Verify Humidifier or Additional Circuit Components
instructions: If a humidifier is in use, ensure it is seated correctly and tubing is fully connected.
Check for any other inline devices (filters, adapters) that may affect flow readings.
Any extra resistance or leaks in these components can trigger a flow sensor alarm.

steps.title: Observe the Ventilator Display
instructions: Note the error code and any additional messages.
Record what you see for documentation purposes.
Philips V60 often displays a specific flow sensor error with a code — writing it down helps CE staff track recurring issues.

steps.title: Try a Simple Reset
instructions: Power off the ventilator.
Reseat the circuit and flow sensor connections.
Power back on and rerun the self-test.
If the error clears, the ventilator may be returned to service. If not, escalate.

CCR.Complaint: Ventilator fails self-test; flow sensor error.
CCR.Cause: Circuit and flow sensor inspected and reseated, humidifier checked, no visible damage. Error persists. Suspected internal flow sensor or electronic issue.
CCR.Resolution: Removed ventilator from service, labeled out of service, sent for repair or tagged for bench evaluation by CE.

helpfulDetails: Any visible damage, moisture, or condensation
Final disposition (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: Welch Allyn Connex 6000 Series – NIBP Failure
description: Basic troubleshooting for a Welch Allyn Connex 6000 monitor reporting NIBP failure due to leaky hose or transducer drift.

steps.title: Inspect the NIBP Hose
instructions: Ensure the hose connecting the cuff to the monitor is fully seated at both ends.
Look for cracks, holes, kinks, or wear along the hose.
Replace the hose if any visible damage or leaks are observed.
Even a small leak can prevent proper inflation and trigger an NIBP error.

steps.title: Check the Cuff and Connections
instructions: Confirm the cuff is the correct size for the patient.
Make sure the cuff tubing is fully inserted and the hook/Velcro is secure.
Inspect for tears or leaks in the bladder.
A poorly seated or damaged cuff can cause failed or inaccurate readings.

steps.title: Verify the Module / Transducer Seating
instructions: Make sure the NIBP module is fully inserted in the monitor.
Check the connector pins for cleanliness and damage.
Look for visible moisture or debris.
Loose or misaligned transducers can cause drift or persistent errors.

steps.title: Observe the Display
instructions: Note any error codes (e.g., “NIBP Fail,” “Low Pressure,” “Leak Detected”).
Record whether the error happens immediately or intermittently.
Documenting details helps CE staff identify recurring issues.

steps.title: Try a Simple Reset
instructions: Remove the cuff and hose from the patient.
Power cycle the monitor.
Reconnect the hose and cuff, and attempt another measurement.
If the measurement succeeds, the issue may have been a temporary connection or seating problem.

CCR.Complaint: NIBP measurement failed; error displayed.
CCR.Cause: Hose inspected and intact, cuff verified, module seated correctly. Measurement still fails. Suspected transducer drift or internal module fault.
CCR.Resolution: Removed monitor from service, labeled Out of Service, sent for repair or tagged for bench evaluation by CE.

helpfulDetails: Final disposition (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: Philips V60 Ventilator – Fails Self-Test / Leak Detected
description: Basic troubleshooting when a Philips V60 ventilator fails its self-test due to a leak detected.

steps.title: Check the Patient Circuit and Tubing
instructions: Make sure the breathing circuit is fully connected at all connection points.
Confirm there are no loose fittings, cracks, or obvious holes in the tubing.
Ensure the circuit is properly seated on the ventilator outlet.
Even a small gap or loose connection can cause a leak failure during self-test.

steps.title: Inspect the Exhalation Port and Filter
instructions: Verify the exhalation port is installed correctly.
Check that the filter is present and seated properly.
Look for moisture buildup or blockage that could affect airflow.
Improper installation or obstruction can cause the ventilator to detect a leak.

steps.title: Check the Humidifier (If Installed)
instructions: Confirm the humidifier chamber is seated correctly.
Make sure the chamber is not cracked or leaking.
Verify all humidifier tubing connections are tight.
Leaks in the humidifier setup are a common cause of failed leak tests.

steps.title: Inspect the Mask or Test Plug
instructions: If a mask is attached, make sure it is sealed properly.
If running a self-test without a patient, ensure the test plug or circuit is capped correctly.
An open or poorly sealed patient interface will cause the self-test to fail.

steps.title: Try a Simple Reset
instructions: Power the ventilator off.
Re-seat the circuit, exhalation port, and humidifier connections.
Power the ventilator back on and rerun the self-test.
If the self-test passes, the ventilator may be returned to service.

CCR.Complaint: Ventilator fails self-test; leak detected.
CCR.Cause: Patient circuit, exhalation port, and humidifier inspected and reseated. No visible damage noted. Self-test continues to fail with leak detected. Suspected internal leak or valve failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed ventilator from service, labeled out of service, sent for repair or tagged for bench evaluation.

helpfulDetails: Final disposition (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: ZOLL R Series – Printer Not Printing / Paper Jam (Thermal Paper)
description: Troubleshooting for ZOLL R Series defibrillator when the printer will not print or reports a paper jam using thermal paper.

steps.title: Check the Paper Stack
instructions: Ensure there is a paper stack loaded in the printer’s tray.
Confirm the leading edge of the top sheet is correctly positioned in the feed mechanism.
Replace the stack if it is empty, wrinkled, or damaged.
Note: Thermal paper is sensitive to heat, pressure, and folds. Crumpled or old paper may not feed properly or print.

steps.title: Inspect for Paper Jams
instructions: Open the printer cover and remove any misfed or stuck sheets.
Look for small bits of torn paper or debris blocking the feed path.
Ensure the feed path is clear before closing the cover.
Thermal paper jams can occur if the stack is compressed too tightly or the edges are bent.

steps.title: Verify Printer Cover is Closed Properly
instructions: The printer will not operate if the cover is not fully closed.
Close the printer cover until it clicks into place.

steps.title: Try a Known-Good Thermal Paper Stack (If Available)
instructions: If the printer still fails to print, replace the current stack with a new, known-good thermal paper stack.
Attempt a test print or generate a report from the device.

steps.title: Observe the Device Display
instructions: Note exactly what the display or status indicator shows: “Paper Jam”, “Printer Error”, or “Insert Paper”.
Record the message for documentation and trend tracking.

CCR.Complaint: Printer will not print / paper jam.
CCR.Cause: Paper stack loaded and properly seated, but printer still displays jam error. Paper cleared and cover closed. Suspected printer mechanism or thermal feed issue.
CCR.Resolution: Replaced thermal paper stack and cleared feed path; printer now functional.

helpfulDetails: Paper stack loaded correctly and in good condition: yes / no
Final status (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: ZOLL R Series – Pads Not Detected / Therapy Cable Failure
description: Troubleshooting for ZOLL R Series defibrillator when pads are not detected, often due to a therapy cable failure.

steps.title: Check That the Pads Are Connected Properly
instructions: Ensure both therapy pads are securely attached to the therapy cable.
Confirm the pads are fully inserted into the connector port on the defibrillator.
Loose connections can prevent the device from recognizing the pads.

steps.title: Inspect the Pads and Cable for Damage
instructions: Look for cracked or torn pads, exposed wires, frayed or twisted cable.
Replace pads or cable if any visible damage is present.
Even small damage can cause the device to detect a failure.

steps.title: Try a Known-Good Pad Set or Cable (If Available)
instructions: Remove the current pads or therapy cable and connect a known-good set.
Observe if the defibrillator recognizes them correctly.
This helps determine whether the issue is with the cable, pads, or device itself.

steps.title: Observe the Device Display
instructions: Note exactly what the display or status indicator shows: “Pads Not Detected” or “Therapy Cable Failure”.
Pay attention to whether the message appears immediately or intermittently.
Even small details help identify intermittent cable or connector issues.

steps.title: Check Pad Expiration
instructions: Verify that the pads are within their expiration date.
Expired pads may not properly connect or be recognized by the device.

CCR.Complaint: Defibrillator reports pads not detected / therapy cable failure.
CCR.Cause: Pads and cable inspected, no visible damage. Tested with known-good pads/cable: issue resolved. Suspected faulty therapy cable.
CCR.Resolution: Removed faulty cable/pads from service and replaced with known-good set.

helpfulDetails: Pads/cable inspected for damage: yes / no
Final status (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: ZOLL R Series – Battery Fails Self-Test
description: Basic battery troubleshooting for a ZOLL R Series defibrillator reporting a failed self-test.

steps.title: Make Sure the Battery Is Fully Seated
instructions: Confirm the battery is installed correctly in the defibrillator.
Remove the battery and reinsert it, making sure it clicks or seats firmly into place.
A loose battery can cause self-test failures even if the battery itself is good.

steps.title: Check the Battery Contacts
instructions: Inspect the battery and device contacts for dirt or debris.
Look for corrosion or bent or damaged pins.
If safe to do so, gently clean visible debris from the contacts and reinsert the battery.
Poor contact between the battery and device can cause charging and self-test issues.

steps.title: Verify the Battery Has Been Charging
instructions: Confirm the defibrillator has been plugged into AC power when stored.
Check for any charging or status indicators that show the battery has been receiving power.
A battery that has not been charging may fail self-test due to low capacity.

steps.title: Try a Known-Good Battery (If Available)
instructions: Remove the current battery and insert a known-good battery from another unit.
Allow the unit to complete its self-test again.
This helps determine whether the issue is with the battery or the defibrillator itself.

steps.title: Observe the Self-Test Message or Indicator
instructions: Note exactly what the display or status indicator shows.
Does it say "Battery Fail"?
Does it say "Replace Battery"?
Does it fail immediately or after charging?
Even small details can help determine the cause.

CCR.Complaint: Defibrillator reports battery failed self-test.
CCR.Cause: Battery fails self-test after reseating and charging. Alternate battery passes self-test. Suspected failed battery pack.
CCR.Resolution: Removed battery from service and replaced with known-good battery.

helpfulDetails: Final status (battery replaced or sent for repair)

title: GE B850 Monitor – Power Issue / Will Not Turn On
description: Basic power troubleshooting for a GE B850 patient monitor.

steps.title: Make Sure the Monitor Has Power
instructions: Confirm the monitor is plugged into an outlet that you know is working.
If unsure, plug in another device (lamp, phone charger, etc.) to test the outlet.
If the monitor is plugged into a power strip or isolation transformer, make sure that device is also turned on.

steps.title: Check the Power Cord
instructions: Look over the power cord for cuts, fraying, or bent/broken prongs.
Make sure the cord is pushed in firmly at both the wall outlet and the back of the monitor.
Loose connections can make the monitor appear dead even when power is available.

steps.title: Confirm the Power Switch Is On
instructions: Locate the power switch on the monitor.
Make sure it is set to the ON position.
Try pressing the front power button again.

steps.title: Watch for Any Signs of Life
instructions: When attempting to power on, observe the monitor closely.
Do any lights turn on? Does the screen flash briefly? Do you hear a fan or clicking sound?
Even small signs can help determine what is happening internally.

steps.title: Try a Known-Good Power Cord (If Available)
instructions: Swap it with the current one.
Try powering the monitor on again.
A faulty cord can look perfectly normal from the outside.

CCR.Complaint: Monitor will not power on.
CCR.Cause: Monitor shows no power with known-working outlet and known-good power cord. No indicator lights or screen activity observed. Suspected internal power failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed from service and sent for repair or tagged out of service for further bench evaluation.

helpfulDetails: Final status (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: Baxter SIGMA Spectrum Infusion Pump – Occlusion Alarm / Will Not Start Infusion
description: Basic troubleshooting when a SIGMA Spectrum infusion pump shows an occlusion alarm and will not start infusion.

steps.title: Check the IV Set and Tubing
instructions: Make sure the tubing is properly loaded into the pump.
Confirm there are no kinks, twists, or sharp bends in the line.
Check that clamps are fully open and not blocking fluid flow.
Even a small pinch or bend can trigger an occlusion alarm.

steps.title: Inspect the Pump Door and Cassette
instructions: Ensure the cassette or disposable set is seated correctly.
Close the door fully — the pump may not start if it senses the door is ajar.
Some alarms are triggered if the cassette isn’t aligned properly.

steps.title: Check the Fluid Bag or Syringe
instructions: Make sure there is fluid in the bag or syringe.
Confirm that the tubing is primed — air in the line can sometimes trigger an occlusion alarm.

steps.title: Observe the Pump Display and Alarm
instructions: Look for any other messages on the display.
Note the type of alarm shown (for example: occlusion, warning, or low fluid).
Record what you see — this helps when documenting.

steps.title: Try a Simple Reset
instructions: Stop the pump.
Remove and reload the tubing.
Close the door and restart the pump.
If the alarm clears, the pump may resume infusion.

CCR.Complaint: Pump will not start infusion; occlusion alarm displayed.
CCR.Cause: Tubing and cassette inspected, tubing free of kinks, door fully closed, fluid present. Alarm persists. Suspected internal pump sensor issue.
CCR.Resolution: Removed pump from service, labeled out of service, sent for repair or tagged for bench evaluation.

helpfulDetails: Any unusual sounds or display behavior
Final disposition (returned to service or sent for repair)
